verses.text: After these \add things\add* Paul departed from Athens, and came to Corinth;
and found a certain Jew named Aquila, born in Pontus, lately come from Italy, with his wife Priscilla; (because that Claudius had commanded all Jews to depart from Rome:) and came unto them.
And because \add he\add* was of the same craft, he abode with them, and wrought: for \add by\add* their occupation they were tentmakers.
And he reasoned in the synagogue every sabbath, and persuaded \add the\add* Jews and \add the\add* Greeks.
And when Silas and Timotheus were come from Macedonia, Paul was pressed in spirit, and testified to the Jews \add that\add* Jesus \add was\add* Christ.

And when they opposed themselves, and blasphemed, he shook \add his\add* raiment, and said unto them, Your blood \add be\add* upon your own heads; I \add am\add* clean: from henceforth I will go unto the Gentiles.
And he departed thence, and entered into a certain \add manâ€™s\add* house, named Justus, one that worshipped God, whose house joined hard to the synagogue.
And Crispus, the \add chief\add* ruler of the synagogue, believed on the Lord with all his house; and many of the Corinthians hearing believed, and were baptized.
Then spake the Lord to Paul in the night by a vision, Be not afraid, but speak, and hold not thy peace:
for I am with thee, and no \add man\add* shall set on thee to hurt thee: for I have much people in this city.
And he continued \add there\add* a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.
And when Gallio was the deputy of Achaia, the Jews made insurrection with one accord against Paul, and brought him to the judgment seat,
saying, This \add fellow\add* persuadeth men to worship God contrary to the law.

And when Paul was \add now\add* about to open \add his\add* mouth, Gallio said unto the Jews, If it were a matter of wrong or wicked lewdness, O \add ye\add* Jews, reason would that I should bear with you:
but if it be a question of words and names, and \add of\add* your law, look ye \add to it;\add* for I will be no judge of such \add matters\add*.
And he drave them from the judgment seat.
Then all the Greeks took Sosthenes, the \add chief\add* ruler of the synagogue, and beat \add him\add* before the judgment seat. And Gallio cared for none of those \add things\add*.

And Paul \add after this\add* tarried \add there\add* yet a good while, and then took his leave of the brethren, and sailed thence into Syria, and with him Priscilla and Aquila: having shorn \add his\add* head in Cenchrea: for he had a vow.
And he came to Ephesus, and left them there: but he himself entered into the synagogue, and reasoned with the Jews.
When they desired \add him\add* to tarry longer time with them, he consented not;
but bade them farewell, saying, I must by all means keep \add this\add* feast that cometh in Jerusalem: but I will return again unto you, if God will. And he sailed from Ephesus.
And when he had landed at Cesarea, and gone up, and saluted the church, he went down to Antioch.
And after he had spent some time \add there\add*, he departed, and went over \add all\add* the country of Galatia and Phrygia in order, strengthening all the disciples.
And a certain Jew named Apollos, born at Alexandria, an eloquent man, \add and\add* mighty in the scriptures, came to Ephesus.
This \add man\add* was instructed in the way of the Lord; and being fervent in the spirit, he spake and taught diligently the \add things\add* of the Lord, knowing only the baptism of John.
And he began to speak boldly in the synagogue: whom when Aquila and Priscilla had heard, they took him unto \add them\add*, and expounded unto him the way of God more perfectly.
And when he was disposed to pass into Achaia, the brethren wrote, exhorting the disciples to receive him: who, when he was come, helped them much which had believed through grace:
for he mightily convinced the Jews, \add and that\add* publickly, shewing by the scriptures that Jesus was Christ.
